LITTLE ORCHESTRA SOCIETY CONCERTS (continued)
Program 4 - Issue 17
38
This concert will open with Richard Strauss’s incomparable Le Bourgeois Genii'! homme.
The remainder of the program is indefinite at this time, but all stations will be
informed as to its content before its distribution.
Program 5 - Issue 18
The outstanding features of this concert will be two double-violin concertos: the
Concerto in D minor by J. S. Bach, and the Concertante for Two Violins by Spohr,
written about 100 yoars ago. The latter, so far as Mr. Scherman can discover, has
never been done publicly in the United States. The soloists will be the American
twin brothers, Gerald and Wilfred Beal. Another first performance will be William
Mayer’s Music for Strings and Trumpet Obbligato with Robert Nagel, the Society’s
first trumpeter as soloist. The program will be rounded out by Beethoven’s Fourth
Symphony.
Program 6 - Issue 19
The appearance of Pierre Monteux as guest conductor is particularly appropriate:
that is, to have one of the elder statesmen in his craft present works that in his
opinion should not be neglected. Mr. Monteux was delighted with the idea, and the
entire program (as well as the soloist) is of his choosing. There will be a striking
symphony for brass, a first performance anywhere, by a young American, Gunther
Schuller; an overture by Mehul; a piano concerto by Paisiello; and the overture to
Hindemith’s satiric opera, News of the Day. The soloist, Vera Franceschi, is a
young American pianist whose extraordinary talent, in Mr. Monteux’s opinion, has
not yet been widely enough recognized.
Program 7 - Issue 20
Peggy Wood, distinguished actress and singer is an artist ideal for the main feature,
the first performance in this country of the incidental music to Peer Gynt. written
by Norway’s leading composer, Harold Saeverud. The Ibsen text will be presented in
a new English adaptation, and Miss Wood will be assisted by an outstanding actor.
The concert will include the Haydn Violin Concerto No. 1. with Jan Tomasow, concert-
master of the orchestra, as soloist; also a Serenade for Orchestra, by Reger.
Program 8 - Issue 21
Gluck’s opera Orfeo ed Euridice was the first to be done in concert form by the
Society, and was the top preference for a repeat performance. Elena Nikolaidi,
Metropolitan Opera artist who sang the role of Orfeo under Toscanini, was a natural
for this revival. Teresa Stich-Randall will sing as Euridice. Miss Stich-Randall
has been in Europe for the past six years where she has been widely acclaimed in
both opera and concert appearances. Pierrette Alarie, who will sing Eros, is one
of the favorite artists of the Paris Opera.
